title: Metal Bar on Rails mathematical reasoning

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A metal bar of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> can slide with negligible friction on a pair of parallel rails that are inclined at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> from the horizontal, as shown in Figure 1. There is a uniform magnetic field <math alttext="vector B" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> perpendicular to the plane formed by the rails, which are separated by a distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>. A circuit is formed by the bar, the rails, and a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> connected across the top ends of the two rails. The bar and the rails have negligible resistance and are in electrical contact with each other.

In the following, take the positive direction to be parallel to the rails down the incline, and positive current in the circuit to be counterclockwise when viewed from above.
content.question:
(a)

i. On the axes in Figure 2, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"> <mi>I</mi> </math> induced in the circuit as a function of the component of the velocity of the bar parallel to the incline. Your sketch should include positive and negative values of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>.

frqParts.text:
(a)

i. On the axes in Figure 2, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"> <mi>I</mi> </math> induced in the circuit as a function of the component of the velocity of the bar parallel to the incline. Your sketch should include positive and negative values of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the net force <math alttext="F sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> exerted on the bar when the bar is moving with a nonzero speed down the rails. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>M</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>v</mi></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

(b) The rails are repositioned to be horizontal, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, with the magnetic field still perpendicular to the plane formed by the rails. The bar is then given an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> in the positive direction, which is now toward the right.

i. Using the expression for <math alttext="F sub net" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> from part (a)(ii), derive, but do NOT solve, a differential equation for the bar’s velocity <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> when the rails are horizontal. Express your equation in terms of \(v_0\) and time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, as well as <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>M</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. Solve the differential equation from part (b)(i) to derive an expression for the speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> of the bar as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.
